person.tagline: Scholar of climate change, sustainable development, and livelihoods

bio.short: Munyaradzi A. Dzvimbo is a Zimbabwean scholar whose work focuses on climate change, sustainable development, livelihoods, food security, and rural development.
bio.long:
Munyaradzi A. Dzvimbo is a scholar working at the intersection of climate change, sustainable development, and everyday livelihoods. His research spans rural development, food security, environmental governance, and the social dimensions of vulnerability and adaptation—often engaging the realities of communities in Zimbabwe and Southern Africa.

He has previously worked as a high school teacher for more than a decade and has taught in Botswana, Eswatini (Swaziland), and South Africa. He has also worked with community-based environmental and nutrition initiatives in Zimbabwe as a researcher.

currentResearch.title: Gendered Dimensions of Climate Resilience
currentResearch.description: Investigating how female-headed households in rural Zimbabwe adapt to climate variability, focusing on the intersection of poverty, gender roles, and environmental shocks. This work aims to inform gender-sensitive policy frameworks for agrarian communities.

currentResearch.title: Institutional Bioecosystems for Agricultural Extension
currentResearch.description: Analyzing the sustainability of agricultural extension systems and the critical role of traditional institutions. This research explores how harmonizing relationships between service providers and local communities can enhance rural development.

currentResearch.title: Urban Informality & Climate Governance
currentResearch.description: Exploring the political economy of urban informality in Harare and its implications for climate governance. The objective is to identify policy pathways that integrate informal sector resilience into broader urban planning strategies.
